items.headLine: Working At Fairfax
items.slugLine: Well, welcome to 2014. I don't know about you but 2013 was a busy year for all of us here in the engineering teams at Fairfax Media. Like last year, we did another video to thank everyone for their effort and dedication and to take stock of our combined achievements. We thought we'd share it with you.

items.headLine: The Great Apps You Could Work On At Fairfax
items.slugLine: There are many benefits to working at Fairfax Media. One of those are the great apps you will be able to contribute to day-to-day. The Sydney Morning Herald for iPad and The Age for iPad have been featured in the AppStore multiple times. Domain.com.au for iPhone is also one of the most downloaded apps of all time. Contact us for more information on how you can join the team.

items.headLine: Some Highlights of Working at Fairfax Media
items.slugLine: There are many great aspects of working at Fairfax. Unlike other organisations, such as banks, we work in an exciting and fun environment where our focus is on shipping products.

items.headLine: Brown Bag Lunch: Test Driven Development
items.slugLine: TDD focuses on writing automated, failing tests and then writing code to make them pass. We hope you enjoy the video and presentation pack from the talk.

items.headLine: Ethics
items.slugLine: Ethics, sometimes known as philosophical ethics, ethical theory, moral theory, and moral philosophy, is a branch of philosophy that involves systematizing, defending and recommending concepts of right and wrong conduct, often addressing disputes of moral diversity.

items.headLine: Entrepreneur has Branson's ear on jobs
items.slugLine: Sydney entrepreneur Gemma Manning is set to pitch a business idea to Richard Branson aimed at helping disadvantaged women.

items.headLine: Honda reports quarterly loss on strong yen
items.slugLine: For the fiscal year ended March 2016, Honda's profit plunged 32 per cent to Y344.5 billion.

items.headLine: Merlin gets teen makeover in Carmel Niland's young adult series
items.slugLine: Merlin of a new young adult book series is transformed into a ''hot, young wizard'' with wand.

items.headLine: Nancy Knudsen: books that changed me
items.slugLine: Nancy Knudsen has worked in teaching, media and tourism. During a sailing trip around the world for six years with her husband, she spent time living in Istanbul and immersing herself in Turkish culture. Her new book, Accidentally Istanbul (Tamejin Publishing), gives a snapshot of the myths, fables, food and lifestyle of Istanbul. She now lives in Dungog, NSW.

items.headLine: David Astle's search for the old sarspadidious
items.slugLine: Heather Coddington was stumped. Frustrated. Everywhere she turned, no database or dictionary had anything on sarspadidious. "My late father was born in the 1920s," she explained by email. "He used the word to mean really good, or excellent. But I've never been able to find any reference to the slang."

items.headLine: Parramatta's salary cap saga, Bernard Tomic's career earnings and other questions of sport
items.slugLine: If NAPLAN turns education into sport, we would like to redress the balance and turn sport into education. In our test, called NOPLAN, don't stress - everyone's a winner.

items.headLine: SAfrican court's OK to silicosis suit
items.slugLine: Thousands of miners who have contracted silicosis and tuberculosis in South Africa's gold mines will now be able to sue for compensation.

items.headLine: Men by Marie Darrieussecq goes to the dark heart of sex and race
items.slugLine: Men: A Novel of Cinema and Desire

items.headLine: Jodie Fields signs with the ACT Meteors for WNCL
items.slugLine: The ACT Meteors have made a big statement for the 2016-17 cricket season.

items.headLine: German economy accelerates, grows 0.7%
items.slugLine: Growth in the German economy, Europe's biggest, was up from 0.3 per cent in last year's final quarter.

items.headLine: Wall Street dealmaking goes from boom to bust in few months
items.slugLine: Bankers celebrated last year as mergers and acquisitions reached the highest level ever. This year, there's a more dubious record: deals gone bust.

items.headLine: World's oldest person Susannah Mushatt Jones dies in New York
items.slugLine: One of 11 siblings from Alabama, Susannah Mushatt Jones saw two turns of centuries.

items.headLine: CommSec analysis shows ATM use declining as shoppers shift to cashless
items.slugLine: ATMs may be on borrowed time as technical innovations drastically reduce the need for people to carry cash.

items.headLine: European car sales up 9 pct in April
items.slugLine: European carmakers have seen the highest result in volume terms since April 2008, just before the economic crisis hit the automotive industry.

items.headLine: Australian Dami Im into the final of the Eurovision Song Contest
items.slugLine: The Australian contestant is actually in with huge chance of winning Eurovision this Sunday.
